column4: 4. Type "find /boot/grub/stage1". You'll get a response like "(hd0)" or in my case "(hd0,3)". Use whatever your computer spits out for the following lines.

6. Type "setup (hd0,3)". This is key. Other instructions say to use "(hd0)", and that's fine if you want to write GRUB to the MBR. If you want to write it to your linux root partition, then you want the number after the comma, such as "(hd0,3)".
I know it sets up grub
But does it overwrite the MBR
Does it work with the Windows bootloader?
it adds windows to the grub menu
do "sudo mkdir mount/win && sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/hda1 /media/win"
can not create directory, no such file or directory
then do "gksudo nautilus" and navigate to /mount/win and there you are
